properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blowing snow reducing visibilities over the Haines-Skagway Road today. A Pacific storm is moving across the Haines-Skagway Road today. A combination of falling snow and southerly winds gusting to 60 - 80 km/h will produce blowing snow and limited visibilities today. The strongest winds and lowest visibilities will occur near Chilkat Pass. The strong winds and blowing snow will continue through to this evening before abating. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T05:14:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T15:04:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1634034283.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow on the way for tonight. Snow is forecast to begin in the Webequie area late this afternoon. This snow will continue to move northeastward tonight before gradually tapering from west to east on Monday. Total snowfall accumulations near 15 cm can be expected by the time the snow comes to an end Monday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T02:24:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T10:25:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2688718041.2020
Area: Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain event by late Monday ... A band of precipitation will cross the province of Quebec from west to east on Monday. While they will fall as snow over most regions further north, rain is expected south of the St Lawrence Valley. Areas along the Valley and especially just north, such as regions in the north shore of Montreal, Laval and the Lower Laurentians, Lanaudi√®re and Mauricie, should receive freezing rain late in the afternoon or evening that could amount for significant freezing rain accumulations. Untreated surfaces, such as roads, walkways and parking lots, could become icy, slippery and dangerous. There may be a significant impact on the afternoon commute Monday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T06:01:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T14:02:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0720915934.2020
Area: Mont-Tremblant - Sainte-Agathe area, Sainte-Ad√®le - Saint-Sauveur area, Saint-J√©r√¥me area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Laval area, Montr√©al Island area, Soulanges area, Vaudreuil area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area, Louiseville area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-P√©rade area, Trois-Rivi√®res area

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected to continue tonight with total accumulations of 10 to 20 cm. The snow will end in the Meadow Lake region near midnight. For La Ronge and Pelican Narrows, the snow is expected to end by Sunday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-01T17:29:44-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions near White Pass today and Monday. A Pacific storm continues to bring snow and high winds to White Pass resulting in blizzard conditions. Visibilities will improve beyond 400 metres tonight. However, blizzard conditions will return on Monday near White Pass as the winds pick up again to southwest 60 km/h gusting to 80. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T07:01:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T15:02:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0713064170.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged snowfall expected. Total snowfall amounts: generally 10 to 20 cm with locally higher amounts possible around St. John's and vicinity and the Southern Shore. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 60 km/h. Locations: Avalon Peninsula Time Frame: Sunday afternoon until Monday evening. Remarks: Winds are not expected to be severe with this system but will be strong enough to cause poor visibilities in the typical exposed areas that are prone to blowing and drifting snow. The highest snowfall amounts are expected over the eastern side of the Avalon Peninsula. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-01T17:52:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-01T01:53:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0329169524.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow on the way for today. Snow has begun early this morning near the Manitoba border. This snow will continue to move northeastward today and reach the Big Trout Lake area by this afternoon. The snow will taper from west to east tonight. Total snowfall accumulations near 15 cm can be expected by the time the snow comes to an end Monday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system tracking eastward through southern Manitoba is giving snow to east-central Manitoba early this morning. The snow will continue today and then taper off from west to east tonight. Snowfall totals are expected to be in the 10 to 20 cm range, with areas between Norway House and Island Lake likely to receive the most. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 55 and minus 60. Extreme cold conditions will continue tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-01T15:21:07-00:00

Area: Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 60 km/h. Locations: St. John's and vicinity and the Southern Shore Time span: this evening until midday Monday. Remarks: Snow will develop this afternoon and taper off on Monday afternoon, with the heaviest snowfall accumulations expected tonight. Gusty northeasterly winds will accompany the snow causing reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-02T06:30:06-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional amounts: 15 to 25 cm is expected. Locations: eastern mainland Nova Scotia. Time span: today and this evening. Remarks: A trough of low pressure will bring heavy snow to eastern parts of the province today, tapering to light snow and ending this evening. For Halifax - East of Porters Lake, the heaviest snowfall is expected to occur over inland areas east of Ship Harbour. Locations further to the west are likely to see less than five centimetres, beginning late this morning as the system tracks slightly westward before moving offshore this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-02T01:59:41-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. A colder air mass is moving into the area from the Western Arctic tonight. Combined with winds of 10 to 15 km/h, extreme wind chill values of -50 are expected. Conditions should improve for Pond Inlet and Arctic Bay Sunday. Extreme cold wind chill values may return to Clyde River Monday morning before the next low pressure system moves into the area Monday night. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h. Locations: Burin and Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: this evening until midday Monday. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strengthening northeasterly winds this evening to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Monday morning over the Burin Peninsula and near midday over the Avalon Peninsula as the snow tapers off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Sudden reduction in visibility in snow and blowing snow will occur this afternoon and early evening as a cold front blasts through southeast Yukon and northern B.C. Areas near Swan Lake and Swift River will be the most affected by the reduced visibilities. Visibilities will improve early this evening as the winds subside in the wake of the front. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
